Atmos

The dashboard for equitable environments

Atmos helps you manage, compare and analyse indoor environment data all in one place, to help maintain spaces that are comfortable for all.

View Demo

The problem

The thermal comfort models used to guide most buildings are based on 1960s-era studies of college-aged men from northern Europe and America, leaving out the needs of diverse populations. Additionally, designing for a single "average person" isn't equitable, as that person doesn't exist. Yet buildings are still cooled, heated, and ventilated as if they do...
So, how can we better represent and design for an entire population?

Introducing atmos

A dashboard that analyzes real-world indoor environment data to reveal how different people experience your spaces. Our platform lets you:

Explore, compare and spot issues instantly

Dive into any time period, compare conditions across spaces, and customize comfort parameters for focused insights. Leaderboards highlight the least comfortable areas, showing how often each space meets comfort standards—and how that's changing over time.

Visualize patterns and variability

Dive deep into how your spaces perform throughout the week. Atmos combines a heatmap—showing average temperature normalized to each day of the week—with a temperature variability box plot, so you can instantly spot when and where comfort fluctuates most. These visualizations make it easy to pinpoint recurring issues, highlight outliers, and identify HVAC inefficiencies.

Identify long-term trends

Go beyond day-to-day monitoring. Atmos helps you uncover long-term patterns in thermal comfort metrics. Track seasonal shifts, measure the impact of interventions, and make data-driven decisions to optimize your indoor environments over time.

Empower your people

See thermal comfort zones for a wide range of people, not just the "average." Get actionable suggestions for faster, more responsive systems and give occupants more control. Integrated widgets let employees share real-time feedback and receive personalized, context-aware suggestions—making comfort a conversation, not a top-down decree.

This website and application were built with Astro, React, React-Plotly, and SCSS for DECO3100; you can view its log here. All data is sourced from Tom Parkinson at the Indoor Environmental Quality (IEQ) Lab, University of Sydney. Thank you Kaz for the amazing unit, lectures and guidance!
